div.head: TO The Right Reverend Father in God IOHN LORD BISHOP OF EXCESTER.
div.p:
WHen the dark night of our confu≈øions was by Gods wonderful mercy, (never to be forgotten) well nigh at an end, by the near approaching of our Sun, the breath of our no≈øtrils, our dread Soveraign Lord the Kings Maje≈øty, unto the horizon of his paenitent and loyal Subjects in his hereditary Kingdomes and Dominions, whereby
all began to be revived, & to be prepared for the receiving all good impre≈ø≈øions: in this beginning of our happine≈øs, (con≈øidering with my ≈øelf by what be≈øt means men of different apprehen≈øions concerning Eccle≈øia≈øtical things might be brought unto godly unity and meet uniformity therein;) I thought that the knowledge of the ≈øtate of the Church of Chri≈øt in the Apo≈øtles dayes, and in the four Centuries following their times, (as to the form of Eccle≈øia≈øtical Government, Di≈øcipline, Liturgy and Rites, u≈øed in them) would very much conduce to the attainment of that ble≈ø≈øed end. For in tho≈øe dayes many thou≈øands of holy Confe≈ø≈øors and Martyrs flouri≈øhed; in tho≈øe times lived the mo≈øt reverend Fathers of the fir≈øt four general Councils, of Nice, Con≈øtantinople, Ephe≈øus and Chalcedon, celebrated over all the Chri≈øtian world; of who≈øe wi≈ødome and godly care, to do nothing in tho≈øe particulars again≈øt the in≈øtitutions of Chri≈øt and his Apo≈øtles, but rather to do all things as might be mo≈øt plea≈øing to God, and mo≈øt conducing to the edification of the Church, no prudent and charitable man can entertain the lea≈øt doubt: Men they were, and might erre; but that ≈øo many men of extraordinary holine≈ø≈øe and wi≈ødome, compared to the be≈øt men of the≈øe latter Centuries, ≈øhould unanimou≈øly agree
for the ≈øpace of two, three or four hundred years in ≈øetting up and practi≈øing ≈øuper≈øtition, is incredible to them who believe that God hath promi≈øed to teach the humble his way, and ≈øhew his covenant to them that fear him, and not to for≈øake them which have not fir≈øt for≈øaken him. Having therefore rea≈øon and religion to a≈ø≈øure me, that all under≈øtanding and ≈øober men, if they could once ≈øee the form of Church-government, with the Liturgies and Rites u≈øed by tho≈øe Primitive Churches, demon≈øtrated by undeniable te≈øtimonies of pure antiquity, would ea≈øily be induced to embrace them ≈øo far as they ≈øhould appear to be convenient for Chri≈øtian unity and edification, in the pre≈øent circum≈øtances of time, place, and per≈øons, (whereof not private men, but the Governours Civil and Eccle≈øia≈øtical are the onely Judges on earth) I made what inquiry I could, if any book were extant in the Engli≈øh tongue containing a brief, full, and plain demon≈øtration of all the ≈øaid Eccle≈øia≈øtical things, which might be had at a cheap rate, ≈øoon read over, and ea≈øily under≈øtood by all men of indifferent capacity, whereby the knowledge of tho≈øe things might be the more divulged: But, after diligent inquiry, finding none, I re≈øolved (being the work was within the limits of my vocation, and in reading
the ancient writers, I had with no ≈ømall diligence noted the pa≈ø≈øages conducing thereto) invocato Dei Opt. Max. Nomine, to u≈øe my poor talent with my be≈øt indevour to write ≈øuch a little book, which ≈øhould comprehend in it the ≈øum and ≈øub≈øtance of all the matters above ≈øpecified, as briefly, fully and plainly as I could. And this was the beginning of this ≈ømall Treati≈øe; which, being ended in convenient time, was offered to worthy men of excellent indowments to be peru≈øed by them, in hope that one or other of them (knowing the u≈øefulne≈øs of the matter treated of, and ob≈øerving the too plain, low, and uneven manner of writing) would be moved to put forth a work upon that ≈øubject; which (being repleni≈øhed with good variety of well ordered matters, adorned with convenient eloquence, and commended by the worthy name of an Author famous for his learning, eloquence, and vertues) would be by all readily entertained, greedily read, and would ≈øweetly convey the things de≈øired to be publi≈øhed, to the knowledge of all men. But herein my hope failed me: For tho≈øe worthy per≈øons were ≈øo imployed in the high and weighty affaires of the Church, that they had no lei≈øure to go about this, (although an u≈øeful work, yet) of le≈øs profit to the Church and le≈øs proportionable to their great abilities,
then the ≈øublime imployment, wherein their time was ≈øpent. What remained then, but that either that needful work mu≈øt be altogether wanting, or this poor treati≈øe ≈øo void of due ornaments mu≈øt be ≈øuffred to go abroad. I had indeed once in a manner re≈øolved to bury it in my ≈øtudy, but an occa≈øion bringing the matterr into a new debate, I ≈øuffered ≈øome rea≈øons to prevaile with me to give it leave to pre≈øent it ≈øelf to the view of the world; yet not without ≈øome honourable Patron the glorious lu≈øtre of who≈øe great learning, Excellent Vertues and pretious name might both illumminate it, and conciliate for the mean and ob≈øcure author ≈øome room in the good esteem and affection of learned and good men. For which end I thought it mo≈øt convenient to make choi≈øe of one of tho≈øe very bright ≈øtars, which his Maje≈øties wi≈ødome and goodne≈øs had been plea≈øed to ≈øet in the firmament of our Church: among whom your Lord≈øhip was fir≈øt pre≈øented to my thoughts in your very learned, elegant and eloquent works, e≈øpecially both in your te≈øtification of your great and very remarkable zeal for the now mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed and glorious Saint and Martyr our late glorious King CHARLS the fir≈øt, and in your no le≈øs zealous fidelity to our mo≈øt dear and dread Soveraign Lord King CHARLES the ≈øecond, manife≈øted in
times of greate≈øt peril, and al≈øo in your ≈øighs, groans, complaints and prayers for and of the Church of England in her deep di≈øtre≈øs, in your prudent & indefatigable endevours for her re≈øtauration, in tho≈øe parts of your Lord≈øhips mo≈øt learned writings, wherein, as in exceeding fair monuments more la≈øting then bra≈ø≈øe, you con≈øecrate the ble≈ø≈øed Memories of many very precious names, viz. of the right reverend Fathers, Bi≈øhop Andrews, Bi≈øhop Morton, Bi≈øhop Potter, Bi≈øhop Hall, Bi≈øhop Brownrigg, and other honourable per≈øons, never to be remembred without due acknowledgement of their tran≈øcendent worth: and e≈øpecially, of the mo≈øt reverend Father in God, Dr. James U≈øher late Arch-bi≈øhop of Armagh, and Lord Primate of all Ireland; who, in an exact knowledge of all good learning, in depth of judgment, in the due ≈øtating and well cleering controver≈øies of Religion, and in ≈øanctity of life, was not much (if at all) inferior to any the be≈øt of Bi≈øhops ≈øince the Apo≈øtles dayes; And la≈øty, in an acceptable ta≈øt which I have had of the ≈øweetne≈øs of your vertue in a particular favour, for which I pre≈øent my humble thanks to your Lord≈øhip.

May it plea≈øe you, right reverend father, to take this ≈ømall work into your honorable patronage and protection, and, pardoning my boldne≈øs in this attempt,
to take in good part the very humble and hearty tender of my be≈øt ≈øervice to your Lord≈øhip. God Almighty long continue your life and pro≈øperous E≈øtate, and make you a happy instrument of much good to his Church.

div.head: The PREFACE.
div.p:
THis ≈øhort treati≈øe containeth the ≈øum and ≈øub≈øtance of what the reverend Doctors of the Primitive Churches for the fir≈øt four hundred years after the birth of our ble≈ø≈øed Saviour have practi≈øed and written, and thereby tran≈ømitted to our times, concerning Epi≈øcopacy, Presbytery, Eccle≈øia≈øtical Di≈øcipline, Liturgy and Ceremonies, omitting onely tho≈øe which appear to be impertinent to the ≈øtate and condition of the pre≈øent times. Every material point herein is proved out of authors received by all ≈øides (which cau≈øed the omi≈øsion of the te≈øtimony of Ignatius, &c.) and ≈øuch authors again≈øt whom it cannot be rea≈øonably pre≈øumed, that they were deceived or erred in their relation of matters of fact and practi≈øe, done or u≈øed in the times, wherein they them≈øelves or tho≈øe with whom they conver≈øed, did live. The authorities were not collected by the help of tables, or received from ≈øecond hands (whence mi≈øtakes do ea≈øily and u≈øually ari≈øe) but were taken from the authors own work read and duely con≈øidered. Becau≈øe the Holy Scripture by rea≈øon of humane infirmities in all, and perver≈øene≈øs in many, is in many parts thereof-diver≈øely under≈øtood, it is very needful (≈øaith Vincentius Lirinen≈øis) that the line of Prophetical and Apo≈øtolical interpretation be directed according to the rule of Eccle≈øia≈øtical and Catholick ≈øen≈øe. And al≈øo in the very Catholick Church great care mu≈øt be had,Adver≈øus haere≈ø. c. 2. (≈øaith the ≈øame ancient author) that we hold that
which hath been believed every where, alwayes, and by all. Which direction of this di≈øcreet Writer,In ip≈øa item Catholica Eccle≈øia magnopre curandum e≈øt, ut id teneamus quod ubique, quod ≈øemper, quod ab omnibus creditum e≈øt. c. 3. rightly under≈øtood and applied, is very good, and is and hath been of ≈øingular u≈øe, e≈øpecially again≈øt Schi≈ømaticks and Hereticks. For when the con≈øent of the Catholick Church in her principal members in all the parts of the world, and in all ages, beginning in, and proceeding from the Apo≈øtolicall times, unto any other ≈øet or propo≈øed age, doth clearly appear to be in any Divine Doctrine, Di≈øcipline, Liturgie, Rites, or any Eccle≈øia≈øticall u≈øage, who can gain≈øay that unanimous judgment of all the Saints of God, which is a far better interpreter of the word of God, then any generall councell can be? who dare refu≈øe to embrace the ≈øentence of that ju≈øt and impartiall Iudge, except in decrees about things in their nature and morally mutable, which may by the good leave of that Judge be with honour layed a≈øide, when they become unprofitable or di≈ø≈øentaneous to the edification and peace of the Church? The Eccle≈øia≈øticall in≈øtitutions which want ≈øufficient evidence to prove their approbation by the Church flouri≈øhing in the Apo≈øtles dayes, and are found to have the generall approbation of the Churches between the times of the Apo≈øtles, and about the year of our Lord 500, although they be of le≈øs e≈øteem and regard then the in≈øtitutions known to be received by the Apo≈øtolicall Church, yet are they Venerable and worthy of very great regard: partly, becau≈øe of the propinquity of tho≈øe Churches, to the time of the Apo≈øtles, from whom ≈øome of them might be probably thought to be derived, although a certaine proofe of their derivation appeared not to ≈øucceeding ages: partly becau≈øe of the eminent wi≈ødome of the Fathers, and exemplary ≈øanctity of the Churches in tho≈øe times, in compari≈øon of the Churches in the following Generations. The Churches of this ≈øpace of time; that is, between the Apo≈øtles decea≈øe and the
year 500. wanted the extraordinary Apo≈øtolicall Spirit, which ≈øo guided the Church, planted by them in all publick re≈øolutions, that ≈øhe would make no Ordinance without the Apo≈øtles approbation, and having it, ≈øhe could not erre in her determinations. All other Churches therefore might ea≈øily erre, and they that upon good occa≈øion given them would mode≈øty affirm, that they did erre in ≈øome con≈øtitutions and u≈øages generally approved by them, and al≈øo in ≈øome remote conclu≈øions of the Divine Doctrine, are not to be thought to di≈øparage them, ≈øeeing upon the matter they ≈øay no more, then that they were men which wanted the guide of the holy Spirit to lead them infallibly to truth and goodne≈øs in all things of Eccle≈øia≈øticall concernment; but that tho≈øe Churches within the fir≈øt 500 years erred in any publick con≈øtitutions or cu≈øtomes unto Idolatry, or, which is le≈øs, unto apparent ≈øuper≈øtition, is a thing improbable and incredible to them, who rightly con≈øider the publick doctrine and Eccle≈øia≈øticall Ordinances of tho≈øe times, and take due notice of the great prudence and holine≈øs of many of the chief Governors and Pillars of tho≈øe Churches; Hereticks, Idolaters and ≈øuper≈øtitious per≈øons were in many of the Churches, but that the Churches them≈øelves in any part of that time became Haereticall, Idolatrous, or Super≈øtitious, is very untrue and unworthy the thought of a prudent and charitable man. And here by the way, concerning the Church of England, if we compare her in her legall con≈øtitution with any other Church after the year of our Lord 180. it will be found that they who charge her with Antichri≈øtiani≈øme, Idolatry, or Super≈øtition in her con≈øtitution, e≈øtabli≈øhed by Law, do by clear con≈øequence pa≈øs the ≈øentence of the ≈øame condemnation upon every of tho≈øe Churches, e≈øpecially them of the 4th and 5th century: the ra≈øhne≈øs and inju≈øtice of which cen≈øure is very worthy of a very ≈øevere cen≈øure. The Apo≈øtle, indeed,
≈øaith that the my≈øtery of iniquity began to work in his time:2 The≈ø. 2.7. Revel. 2.24. but did he meane thereby that the my≈øterious iniquity and depth of Satan, began to work in the publick con≈øtitutions of the Catholick Church in his dayes, and that they were parts of the con≈øtitutions? no ≈øurely, neither can any Chri≈øtian be ≈øo ≈øimple or ≈øo injurious to the Mini≈øtery of the Apo≈øtles, and the purity of that Church, as to think that the Apo≈øtle had any ≈øuch meaning. The my≈øtery of Iniquity was indeed in the Church in ≈øome dead branches, in ≈øome wicked livers and Haereticks, but it was not of the Church, it was no part of the con≈øtitution of the Church, although it did labour to in≈øinuate and work it ≈øelf into it: it may be granted as very probable, that the my≈øtery of iniquity in particular, and tho≈øe dead members, and by them working upon the Churches, might more vitiate the Churches of the ≈øecond century then the Churches in the fir≈øt century, and the Churches in the third century, more then the Churches of the ≈øecond and ≈øo of the re≈øt to the end of the fifth century; but that in any part of that time it prevailed ≈øo far, as to become a part of the Eccle≈øia≈øticall Doctrine, Di≈øcipline, Liturgy or Ceremonies univer≈øally received and u≈øed, is rather a ≈øurmi≈øe of an exce≈øs of jealou≈øy, then an opinion grounded upon probable rea≈øons, it is ≈øo far from being an approved truth. After the year 500. and the divi≈øion of the Empire, and e≈øtabli≈øhment of the Kings,2 The≈ø. 2.3. Revel. 17.12, 13.16. which were to give their power and ≈øtrength to the Bea≈øt, and which in due time were to burn the Whore of Babylon, the Churches grew generally more and more corrupt; the civill and Eccle≈øia≈øticall confu≈øions attending the Warrs in the ≈øeverall Provinces, giving advantage to the my≈øtery of Iniquity, to mingle it ≈øelf, fir≈øt with the Di≈øcipline and Ceremonies, and after with the publick Doctrine; whereby, fir≈øt ≈øuper≈øtition, then Idolatry, and la≈øtly, Here≈øies took place in the publick profe≈ø≈øion of the
Churches; ≈øo that in per≈øons who knowingly ≈øwallowed the good and bad together, the infection of the my≈øtery of Iniquity hindred the operation of the good portion of the whole lump, and working the effect of its poy≈øon into their vital parts, corrupted and de≈øtroyed them. And therefore the≈øe latter Churches were not by the fir≈øt reformers of our Church propo≈øed, for patterns, as the former were, which pre≈øerved the purity of Doctrine, Di≈øcipline, and Ceremonies without the addition of any thing cau≈øing Super≈øtition, much le≈øs Idolatry or Haere≈øy. Our Church hath ≈øeparated the Pretious from the Vile, the good of Doctrine, Di≈øcipline, and Rites from the pe≈øtiferous and noxious additions; and now if either the abu≈øe of pro≈øperity, or the iniquity of the late times hath added any evil quality to any of our Eccle≈øia≈øticall things, or made us incapable of good by ≈øome Rite or particle of the Di≈øcipline or Liturgy, or if any defect appear to be in our former reformations, and e≈øpecially if any of the≈øe have happened in any Rite of adoration (wherein is the greate≈øt danger;) it is not to be doubted, but that all the≈øe things will be carefully looked into; and whether by omi≈ø≈øion, explanation or otherwi≈øe, the Di≈øcipline and Rites, by the help and ble≈ø≈øing of God, ≈øhall be reformed according to the be≈øt patterns, and as ≈øhall mo≈øt conduce to the godly unity and peace of the Church and Kingdome. What do I ≈øpeak only of future Reformation? ≈øeeing the deep Wi≈ødome, and the mo≈øt ≈øincere piety of his Sacred Maje≈øty hath by the ble≈ø≈øing of God upon his Royal indeavours, found out the be≈øt temperament for the healing of the pre≈øent di≈øtempers, and by his gratious Declaration hath e≈øtabli≈øhed a mo≈øt happy Interim, the fitte≈øt that could be devi≈øed for the preparing different apprehen≈øions and affections unto an unity, meet to entertain the be≈øt form of a Chri≈øtian Church, which the infirmities of the≈øe la≈øt dayes of the la≈øt time can well bear. The Regicides
of late had proceeded far in breaking down this our Hou≈øe of God, P≈øal. 74. 1 King. 6.7. with their iron tooles, their Axes and Hammers, but as it is ≈øaid of King Solomons Temple, that there was neither Hammer nor Axe nor any toole of iron heard while it was in building, ≈øo our ble≈ø≈øed Solomon in reedifying this decayed hou≈øe of God, doth the work without all iron in≈øtruments, without all unplea≈øing ≈øounds, it goeth on ≈øen≈øim ≈øine ≈øen≈øu, and it is and will be the glorious effect of his Maje≈øties incomparable providence, guided by the mo≈øt gratious direction of God, cunctando re≈øtitui≈ø≈øe rem. But ≈øome of them which will read this ≈ømall tractate, may therein ob≈øerve ≈øome pa≈ø≈øages, which ≈øuppo≈øe the Church of England without the benefit of any proceedings of his Maje≈øty towards her re≈øtauration, and may therefore be ready to cen≈øure the Author as he well de≈øerved, if he had not this ju≈øt Apology, namely, That he can make it good by many witne≈ø≈øes of worthy per≈øons of known integrity that this treati≈øe was ready written five months agon at the lea≈øt, at which time the Author could only write of the ≈øtate and condition of things as they were then, and not as they would be in times to come. If any object, It had been better, if ever, to have publi≈øhed this at that time, for which it ≈øeemes more convenient; to which I ≈øay, That the Con≈øcience of mine own infirmities retarded and had almo≈øt hindred the publication thereof.

div.p: IT having plea≈øed God to choo≈øe for him≈øelf out of ≈øinful men a peculiar people to ≈øet forth his glorious prai≈øes, he never left the world de≈øtitute of heavenly in≈øtitutions and Laws, whereby men might be tran≈ølated from the ≈øtate of ≈øin and mi≈øery, to the ≈øtate of holine≈øs and Salvation, and be made and pre≈øerved an≈øwerable in conver≈øation to the ble≈ø≈øed condition of their tran≈ølation and change.

It appeareth, that it was the intention of our Saviour, that the number of twelve Apo≈øtles ≈øhould be his primary in≈øtruments in founding the Original Churches of Chri≈øt, the Mothers of all other Churches to ≈øucceed unto the end of the world; It was al≈øo his purpo≈øe to make them parents of all other Mini≈øters which ≈øhould ≈øucceed in an ordinary cour≈øe; which is hereby manife≈øt, becau≈øe Chri≈øt promi≈øed to be with them unto the worlds end, which cannot be verified of their per≈øons, and therefore is to be under≈øtood of them in the per≈øons of their ≈øucce≈ø≈øors, proceeding from them by ≈øucce≈ø≈øive ordination, Ba≈øil. con≈øtit. There were three Editions of the covenant of grace, the one from Adam to Abraham, the ≈øecond from him to our Saviour, the third from our Saviour unto the end of the world. Notwith≈øtanding that the Mini≈øters of the fir≈øt and ≈øecond Edition of the Covenant of grace, Sect. 2. had a power of binding and loo≈øing, in having the ≈øpirit accompanying their office and ≈øervice, and that the Apo≈øtles in the mortal life of our Saviour, had the ≈øame in a higher degree; yet the promi≈øe made to the confe≈ø≈øion of St. Peter, of giving unto him a power of binding and loo≈øing with the Keyes of the Kingdome of Heaven was not in vaine, as of a thing which he had already received; for he had received the ≈øame onely in the mea≈øure and degree meet to be di≈øpen≈øed at that time, and not in the ordinary fulne≈øs promi≈øed to the mini≈øters of the new Te≈øtament, fully confirmed by the death and re≈øurrection of Chri≈øt: and therefore our Saviour after his ri≈øing again from the dead, be≈øtowed upon them that promi≈øed fulne≈øs of the Spirit, which was in ordinary to accompany their mini≈øtery of the word, Chry≈øo≈øt. in 2 Cor. hom. 6. I am very apt to believe, that the Churches, which ≈øeem to u≈øe the Presbyterian government, never intended by any Law, de≈øerving the proper name of a Law, to ≈øettle the primitive Presbytery in their Churches, whence the ≈øad Schi≈ømes aro≈øe in the primitive times; much le≈øs to abrogate the ancient Epi≈øcopacy, which in the judgment of the be≈øt Chri≈øtians, and of the Apo≈øtles, is the healer of Schi≈ømes, and the pre≈øerver of peace: But that they intended (as they had good rea≈øon) to abrogate the corrupted Hierarchy, with the multitude of its oppre≈ø≈øing attendants, and (as nece≈ø≈øity compelled them) ≈øeemingly to ≈øu≈øpend their reception of the ancient Epi≈øcopacy, but in very deed receiving in ≈øome hidden ≈øort the ≈øub≈øtance of it, ≈øecretly giving that Authority to the moderator of the Colledge of Presbyters, which tantamounts the Authority of the ancient Bi≈øhops.
